<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18634>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CONFIRMED
     Ever confirmed|0                           |1

--- Comment #3 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
Thanks for the report. For now I've added/fixed checks to assure that select()
and FD_* are called with valid file descriptors.

I agree that on POSIX systems, the maximum allowed descriptor number is
FD_SETSIZE-1. I think it is clear from the POSIX wording as well as Linux and
macOS man pages.

I don't know why the error handling in the socket code has been designed the
way it has been, but I've fixed it consistently with the existing design. Also,
introducing R exceptions where they haven't been before often comes with
introducing new leaks.

Also these checks have to be done differently on Windows. On Windows, the
socket (file) descriptors can be and are arbitrarily large numbers and they are
supported such in select() and FD_*(). The limit, however, (still) applies to
the maximum number of descriptors in the set.

If you could test the new behavior on a system where you observed the crash,
that would be nice. The fixes are in R-devel 85689 (the calls to select/FD_
should be fixed, but the leaks are still present).

*[Bug 18637] New: Tar has not had a 100 byte limit for 35 years. The check is confusing.*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18637>

            Bug ID: 18637
           Summary: Tar has not had a 100 byte limit for 35 years. The
                    check is confusing.
           Product: R
           Version: R 4.3.x
          Hardware: All
                OS: All
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Misc
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:mcgrath.justin@gmail.com|mcgrath.justin@gmail.com>

This is not a bug per se, but a member of the core team on the mailing list
suggesting that I post this here.

The "check_file_names" function in "library/tools/R/check.R" performs checks
for compatibility with the tar v7 and ustar formats. v7 has a 100 byte
restriction on the total path, and if a path is longer than that, a note is
outputted. Tar has not had this limitation for more than 35 years, longer than
R has existed. Thus, there are likely no people installing current versions of
R that do not have support for at least 256 byte paths, and checking for v7
compatibility is not helpful. It is roughly similar to telling users that their
paths are not 8.3 compatible.

Although it is rare that sensibly named files have paths longer than 100 bytes,
it does happen. In particular, publicly available libraries can have sensible
path names around 85 bytes long, which when added in a subdirectory of an R
package exceed 100 bytes. Thus developers see the note and need to rename files
so that R CMD check --as-cran reports no messages in order to send a clean
build to CRAN. Since this requires manually renaming files and editing #include
directives each time an update is pulled from a public source, this task is
frustratingly pointless given that tar has no such limitation.

I think the check for v7 compatibility, that is, paths exceeding 100 bytes, is
unnecessary and causes unnecessary work and could be removed. The ustar check,
up to 256 byte paths with some restrictions on splitting the path, poses no
problem.

The v7 check has served double duty, also helping ensure that packages can be
extracted on Windows, which has a 260 character path limit. A path limit check
would likely need to be added if the v7 check is removed. However, a path limit
of 100 characters is not necessary to ensure usability, and it is unbalanced.
Both packing and unpacking require people to use reasonable names. One can't
expect that people will put unreasonable paths in their packages, and one can't
expect people to try to unpack packages into unreasonably long directories.
Thus there should be a balance between the two.

I suggest 130 characters. Why? Well, if the total path limit were 1000
characters, one would just pick 500, right in the middle, and not think more
about it. Realistically, neither packing nor unpacking will ever be restricted
by that limit. Although 260 characters is small enough that no matter what
split is chosen, there's going to be someone packing or unpacking that has a
problem, it's also big enough that by selecting the value right in the middle,
very few people will ever have problems in either case. There's probably an
optimal value that's not 130 characters, but until people complain about it
either way, it's all guessing, and 130 is a good first guess.

Overall, this makes things clearer and easier for developers. They would not be
given a message about an overly restrictive limitation they know doesn't exist,
and instead they'd be given a meaningful message about a real, but reasonable,
limitation.
